newsitem.title: JAPAN: Malaysian LPG term talks deadlocked -- traders.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian LPG term talks deadlocked -- traders.

text.p: Term talks for Malaysian liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) are stalled, with the exporter seeking a premium of about $34.00 and Japanese buyers suggesting a premium of about $25.00, traders said on Tuesday.

Prices for the current annual term ending this month are set at $38.00 per tonne over Saudi Aramco's contract prices for the first cargo each importer procures, $37.00 for the second lot and $36.00 for the third, they said. Some traders said current prices for Malaysian term cargoes were too high, compared with the term price for Kuwaiti cargoes of $30.00 per tonne above Saudi contract prices.

But they also said that as Malaysia was one of the few Asian crude suppliers to Japan, negotiators wanted to avoid hurting ties with the country by aggressively pushing for a price cut or by walking out of the negotiations.

"The buyers need to be very careful in the price talks because they cannot afford to run the risk of losing a precious non-Middle Eastern crude supplier," one LPG trader said. About 80 percent of Japan's crude comes from the Middle East.
The new prices are expected to set by early 1997 at the latest, traders added.
Saudi Aramco's contract prices are loosely based on the results of three-monthly spot LPG tenders and the company's own assessment of spot market trends.
